properties.name: Chiba Family Magariya
properties.description: Posted by Souteelak 岩手県遠野市綾織町上綾織1－14This is an authentic example of the L-shaped house (called a magariya) that used to be abundant in Tono. This one is still used by the Chiba family. The distinctive L-shape design combined the family living quarters on one side and the horse stables on the other to conserve warmth during the cold winter.

properties.name: Eifukuji Temple
properties.description: Posted by Souteelak   日本大阪府南河内郡太子町大字太子２１４６Eifukuji Temple is known as the site of the kofun (tomb) of Prince Shotoku. It is one of the New Saigoku Pilgrimage of 33 Temples, which was newly selected based on Prince Shotoku’s idea of “harmony” as a priority over all other virtues. In 724, after the death of the prince, the emperor Shomu ordered to build a temple to repose the soul of Prince Shotoku. The temple was burned down by the attack of Nobunaga Oda during the Warring States period, but it was rebuilt by Hideyoshi Toyotomi. If you go up the stone steps, you will see the South Gate. Walk through the gate, and then you will see the houtou (a treasure pagoda), the main hall, and the Shoryo-den (a memorial hall of Prince Shotoku) on your left. In the back of the precinct is the Prince Shotoku’s tomb. Shoryo-den is a designated Important Cultural Property. The principal image worshipped inside is said to be Prince Shotoku’s life-size statue when he was 16. It is said to have been placed in the ancient Imperial Palace in Kyoto but donated to this temple by the emperor Gotoba in 1187. Around the temple there are a lot of places associated with Prince Shotoku. You will be impressed by the length of the history all through which people have paid respect for the Prince.

properties.name: Gohyaku Rakan
properties.description: Posted by Souteelak    This is by far my favorite place in Tono. Several hundred years ago a monk took it upon himself to carve 500 reliefs of Buddhist disciples onto large rocks on this mountainside. Around 380 still remain, eroded over the centuries and covered in moss. If you are looking for a spiritual hike with little chance of running into other tourists, this is the place to go.

properties.name: Kappa Buchi
properties.description: Posted by Souteelak    One of the most famous kappa legends originated here. Some people still believe there might still be a resident kappa, but in my personal opinion I believe he has long since vacated.

properties.name: Konsei-sama of Hodohora
properties.description: Posted by Souteelak    The Hodohora Konsei-sama is the smaller and lesser-known of the two in the Tono area. I actually prefer this one because since it is not well-known, you will have a more private and personal experience. Konsei-sama is apparently a regional animist (with some connections to Shinto) deity that oversees many aspects of life--particularly fertility (it\'s hard not to notice it\'s clearly-phallic shape). It is said that housewives that scrub Konsei-sama with their kitchen scours will have their back pains relieved.
